title: Text Alignment
description: Left, right, center, or justified â€” and why left-aligned usually wins.

hook.text: Left-aligned, right-aligned, centered, or justified â€” each alignment creates a different edge pattern and feeling. Most body text should be left-aligned. Here's why.

buildup.text: Left-aligned (ragged right): consistent left edge, natural word spacing. The default for most reading. Right-aligned: unusual, hard to read for long text, useful for design accents. Centered: no strong edge, formal but hard to scan. Justified: both edges aligned, professional but risks ugly word spacing.

discovery.text: Left-aligned text works because the consistent left edge gives the eye a reliable return point after each line. The ragged right edge actually helps readability â€” each line has a unique shape, making it easier to track.

twist.text: Justified text looks polished but creates 'rivers' â€” visible streams of white space running vertically through paragraphs when word spacing stretches unevenly. Good justification requires hyphenation and careful line-breaking.

climax.text: Set the same paragraph four ways: left, right, center, justified. Read each at normal speed. Left-aligned will feel most natural. Justified looks most formal. Centered is hardest to read. Right-aligned feels backward.

punchline.text: When in doubt, align left. It's readable, clean, and never wrong.

options: Visible streams of white space running vertically through paragraphs due to uneven word spacing
